results.name: a(n) is the number of times that sums 1+-4+-9+-16+-...+-n^2 of the first n squares is zero. There are 2^(n-1) choices for the sign patterns.
comment: The frequency of each possible sum is computed by the Mathematica program without explicitly computing the individual sums.
a(n) is the maximal number of subsets of the first n squares that share the same sum. Cf. A025591, A083309.
link: Alois P. Heinz and Ray Chandler, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..500 (first 240 terms from Alois P. Heinz)
T. D. Noe, Extremal Sums of Sequences
formula: a(n) is half the coefficient of x^0 in the product_{k=1..n} x^(k^2)+x^(k^-2).
example: a(7) = 1 because there is only one sign pattern of the first seven squares that yields zero: 1+4-9+16-25-36+49.
